description: From propense (“inclined, disposed”) +‎ -ity, the former from Latin prōpensus, perfect passive participle of prōpendeō.

entries.meaning: An inclination, disposition, tendency, preference, or attraction.
examples: To the psychologist the religious propensities of man must be at least as interesting as any other of the facts pertaining to his mental constitution. It would seem, therefore, that, as a psychologist, the natural thing for me would be to invite you to a descriptive survey of those religious propensities.
